According to their deeds rather than wealth and social position, as is the case in this world.
i.e., those given their records in their right hand and who are destined for Paradise.
i.e., those given their records in their left hand and who are destined for Hell.
The words can also be understood as a complete sentence, i.e., "The forerunners [in good deeds] are the forerunners [in entering Paradise]."
i.e., shirk (association with Allāh) or disbelief.

ayas.translation: َnwُhtwُʿعْbَmَl āَّnِiʾَaʾ āًmāَẓِʿعَw āًbāَrُt āَّnُkَw āَnْtِm āَhdِyʾَaʾ َnwُlwُqَy āwُnāَkَw

footnotes.text: i.e., semen, which contains the potential for human life.
An alternative meaning has also been given: "...in that We will replace the likes of you [with others upon the earth] and create you [in the Hereafter] in that which you do not know."
At what had happened or remain in a state of shock. Another meaning is "in regret."
Of the great fire of Hell.
In the form of flints or other means by which to ignite fire. Travelers are mentioned because of the special convenience to them, although it is a provision for all people in general.
Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā) confirms absolutely by oath.
The Preserved Slate (al-Lawḥ al-Maḥfūẓ), which is with Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā).
i.e., return the soul to the body, meaning that just as you cannot prevent death when it is decreed, you will not escape the recompense when it is decreed.
By praising Him and declaring Him far above and beyond any failure or imperfection.
Before whom nothing existed. Also, He who is supreme, foremost or uppermost.
Enduring eternally when nothing else remains.
Nothing being above Him. Another meaning is "the Apparent," i.e., evident through His creation and revelation.
Nothing being nearer than Him by way of His knowledge. Another meaning is "the Unapparent," i.e., concealed from man's physical senses.

ayas.translation: ٌryِṣَb َnwُlَmْʿعَt āَmِb ُhَّllāَw ۚ ْmُtnُk āَm َnْyَaʾ ْmُkَʿعَm َwُhَw ۖ āَhyِf ُjgُrْʿعَy āَmَw ِءāَmَّslā َnِm ُlِznَy āَmَw āَhْnِm ُjgُrْhkَy āَmَw ِḍْrَaʾْlā yِf ُjgِlَy āَm ُmَlْʿعَy ۚ ِhsْrَʿعْlā yَlَʿع ٰyَwَtْsā َّmُht ٍmāَّyَaʾ ِhَّtِs yِf َḍْrَaʾْlāَw ِtāَwāَmَّslā َqَlَhk yِhdَّlā َwُh

footnotes.text: See footnotes to <reference chapter="2" verses="19">2:19</reference> and <reference chapter="7" verses="54">7:54</reference>.
In knowledge - observing and witnessing.

ayas.translation: ٌryِbَk ٌrْjgَaʾ ْmُhَl āwُqَfnَaʾَw ْmُknِm āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlāَf ۖ ِhyِf َnyِfَlْhkَtْsُّm mُkَlَʿعَjg āَّmِm āwُqِfnَaʾَw ِhِlwُsَrَw ِhَّllāِb āwُnِmāʾ

footnotes.text: In ways pleasing to Allāh.

ayas.translation: ٌryِbَhk َnwُlَmْʿعَt āَmِb ُhَّllāَw ۚ ٰyَnْsُḥْlā ُhَّllā َdَʿعَw āًّlُkَw ۚ āwُlَtāَqَw ُdْʿعَb nِm āwُqَfnَaʾ َnyِhdَّlā َnِّm ًhَjgَrَd ُmَẓْʿعَaʾ َkِyʾٰـَlwُaʾ ۚ َlَtāَqَw ِḥْtَfْlā ِlْbَq nِm َqَfnَaʾ ْnَّm mُknِm yِwَtْsَy āَl ۚ ِḍْrَaʾْlāَw ِtāَwāَmَّslā ُhtāَryِm ِhَّlِlَw ِhَّllā ِlyِbَs yِf āwُqِfnُt āَّlَaʾ ْmُkَl āَmَw

ُmyِẓَʿعْlā ُzْwَfْlā َwُh َkِlَٰhd ۚ āَhyِf َnyِdِlāَhk ُrāَhْnَaʾْlā āَhِtْḥَt nِm yِrْjgَt ٌtāَّnَjg َmْwَyْlā ُmُkāَrْhsُb mِhِnāَmْyَaʾِbَw ْmِhyِdْyَaʾ َnْyَb mُhُrwُn ٰyَʿعْsَy ِtāَnِmْwʾُmْlāَw َnyِnِmْwʾُmْlā yَrَt َmْwَy

ُbāَhdَʿعْlā ِhِlَbِq nِm ُhُrِhāَẓَw ُhَmْḥَّrlā ِhyِf ُhُnِṭāَb ٌbāَb ُhَّl ٍrwُsِb mُhَnْyَb َbِrُḍَf āًrwُn āwُsِmَtْlāَf ْmُkَءāَrَw āwُʿعِjgْrā َlyِq ْmُkِrwُّn nِm ْsِbَtْqَn āَnwُrُẓnā āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlِl ُtāَqِfāَnُmْlāَw َnwُqِfāَnُmْlā ُlwُqَy َmْwَy

footnotes.text: To where light was acquired, i.e., in the worldly life.
By hypocrisy or by falling into temptations.

ayas.translation: َnwُqِsāَf ْmُhْnِّm ٌryِhtَkَw ۖ ْmُhُbwُlُq ْtَsَqَf ُdَmَaʾْlā ُmِhْyَlَʿع َlāَṭَf ُlْbَq nِm َbāَtِkْlā āwُtwُaʾ َnyِhdَّlāَk āwُnwُkَy āَlَw ِّqَḥْlā َnِm َlَzَn āَmَw ِhَّllā ِrْkِhdِl ْmُhُbwُlُq َʿعَhsْhkَt nَaʾ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlِl ِnْaʾَy ْmَlَaʾ

footnotes.text: That similarly, Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā) can soften a heart after its hardness and guide one who had previously been astray.
Another accepted meaning is "And those who have believed in Allāh and His messengers - they are the supporters of truth. And the martyrs, with their Lord, will have their reward and their light."

ayas.translation: ِrwُrُغْlā ُʿعāَtَm āَّlِiʾ āَyْnُّdlā ُhāَyَḥْlā āَmَw ۚ ٌnāَwْḍِrَw ِhَّllā َnِّm ٌhَrِfْغَmَw ٌdyِdَhs ٌbāَhdَʿع ِhَrِhkāʾْlā yِfَw ۖ āًmāَṭُḥ ُnwُkَy َّmُht āًّrَfْṣُm ُhāَrَtَf ُjgyِhَy َّmُht ُhُtāَbَn َrāَّfُkْlā َbَjgْʿعَaʾ ٍhtْyَغ ِlَhtَmَk ۖ ِdāَlْwَaʾْlāَw ِlāَwْmَaʾْlā yِf ٌrُhtāَkَtَw ْmُkَnْyَb ٌrُhkāَfَtَw ٌhَnyِzَw ٌwْhَlَw ٌbِʿعَl āَyْnُّdlā ُhāَyَḥْlā āَmَّnَaʾ āwُmَlْʿعā

ِmyِẓَʿعْlā ِlْḍَfْlā wُhd ُhَّllāَw ۚ ُءāَhsَy nَm ِhyِtْwʾُy ِhَّllā ُlْḍَf َkِlَٰhd ۚ ِhِlُsُrَw ِhَّllāِb āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlِl ْtَّdِʿعُaʾ ِḍْrَaʾْlāَw ِءāَmَّslā ِḍْrَʿعَk āَhُḍْrَʿع ٍhَّnَjgَw ْmُkِّbَّr nِّm ٍhَrِfْغَm ٰyَlِiʾ āwُqِbāَs
ٌryِsَy ِhَّllā yَlَʿع َkِlَٰhd َّnِiʾ ۚ āَhَaʾَrْbَّn nَaʾ ِlْbَq nِّm ٍbāَtِk yِf āَّlِiʾ ْmُkِsُfnَaʾ yِf āَlَw ِḍْrَaʾْlā yِf ٍhَbyِṣُّm nِm َbāَṣَaʾ āَm

footnotes.text: i.e., the Preserved Slate (al-Lawḥ al-Maḥfūẓ).

ayas.translation: ٍrwُhkَf ٍlāَtْhkُm َّlُk ُّbِḥُy āَl ُhَّllāَw ۗ ْmُkāَtāʾ āَmِb āwُḥَrْfَt āَlَw ْmُkَtāَf āَm ٰyَlَʿع āْwَsْaʾَt āَlْyَkِّl

footnotes.text: Refusing to spend for Allāh's cause or refusing obedience to Him.

ayas.translation: َnwُqِsāَf ْmُhْnِّm ٌryِhtَkَw ۖ ٍdَtْhُّm mُhْnِmَf ۖ َbāَtِkْlāَw َhَّwُbُّnlā āَmِhِtَّyِّrُhd yِf āَnْlَʿعَjgَw َmyِhāَrْbِiʾَw āًḥwُn āَnْlَsْrَaʾ ْdَqَlَw

َnwُqِsāَf ْmُhْnِّm ٌryِhtَkَw ۖ ْmُhَrْjgَaʾ ْmُhْnِm āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَnْyَtāʾَf ۖ āَhِtَyāَʿعِr َّqَḥ āَhْwَʿعَr āَmَf ِhَّllā ِnāَwْḍِr َءāَغِtْbā āَّlِiʾ ْmِhْyَlَʿع āَhāَnْbَtَk āَm āَhwُʿعَdَtْbā ًhَّyِnāَbْhَrَw ًhَmْḥَrَw ًhَfْaʾَr ُhwُʿعَbَّtā َnyِhdَّlā ِbwُlُq yِf āَnْlَʿعَjgَw َlyِjgnِiʾْlā ُhāَnْyَtāʾَw َmَyْrَm ِnْbā yَsyِʿعِb āَnْyَّfَqَw āَnِlُsُrِb mِhِrāَhtāʾ ٰyَlَʿع āَnْyَّfَq َّmُht

ٌmyِḥَّr ٌrwُfَغ ُhَّllāَw ۚ ْmُkَl ْrِfْغَyَw ِhِb َnwُhsْmَt āًrwُn ْmُkَّl lَʿعْjgَyَw ِhِtَmْḥَّr nِm ِnْyَlْfِk ْmُkِtْwʾُy ِhِlwُsَrِb āwُnِmāʾَw َhَّllā āwُqَّtā āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: As long as they refuse to believe in the message of Allāh which was conveyed through Muḥammad (ﷺ).
See footnote to <reference chapter="2" verses="19">2:19</reference>.

ayas.translation: ٌryِṣَb ٌʿعyِmَs َhَّllā َّnِiʾ ۚ āَmُkَrُwāَḥَt ُʿعَmْsَy ُhَّllāَw ِhَّllā yَlِiʾ yِkَtْhsَtَw āَhِjgْwَz yِf َkُlِdāَjgُt yِtَّlā َlْwَq ُhَّllā َʿعِmَs ْdَq ِmyِḥَّrlā ِnٰـَmْḥَّrlā ِhَّllā ِmْsِb

ٌrwُfَغ ٌّwُfَʿعَl َhَّllā َّnِiʾَw ۚ āًrwُzَw ِlْwَqْlā َnِّm āًrَknُm َnwُlwُqَyَl ْmُhَّnِiʾَw ۚ ْmُhَnْdَlَw yِyʾāَّllā āَّlِiʾ ْmُhُtāَhَّmُaʾ ْnِiʾ ۖ ْmِhِtāَhَّmُaʾ َّnُh āَّm mِhِyʾāَsِّn nِّm mُknِm َnwُrِhāَẓُy َnyِhdَّlā

footnotes.text: The saying by a husband to his wife, "You are to me like the back of my mother," meaning unlawful to approach. This was a type of divorce practiced by the Arabs before the prophethood of Muḥammad (ﷺ).

ayas.translation: ٌryِbَhk َnwُlَmْʿعَt āَmِb ُhَّllāَw ۚ ِhِb َnwُẓَʿعwُt ْmُkِlَٰhd ۚ āَّsāَmَtَy nَaʾ ِlْbَq nِّm ٍhَbَqَr ُryِrْḥَtَf āwُlāَq āَmِl َnwُdwُʿعَy َّmُht ْmِhِyʾāَsِّn nِm َnwُrِhāَẓُy َnyِhdَّlāَw

ٌmyِlَaʾ ٌbāَhdَʿع َnyِrِfāَkْlِlَw ۗ ِhَّllā ُdwُdُḥ َkْlِtَw ۚ ِhِlwُsَrَw ِhَّllāِb āwُnِmْwʾُtِl َkِlَٰhd ۚ āًnyِkْsِm َnyِّtِs ُmāَʿعْṭِiʾَf ْʿعِṭَtْsَy ْmَّl nَmَf ۖ āَّsāَmَtَy nَaʾ ِlْbَq nِm ِnْyَʿعِbāَtَtُm ِnْyَrْhَhs ُmāَyِṣَf ْdِjgَy ْmَّl nَmَf

footnotes.text: See footnote to <reference chapter="4" verses="92">4:92</reference>.
See footnote to <reference chapter="4" verses="79">4:79</reference>.

ayas.translation: ٌmyِlَʿع ٍءْyَhs ِّlُkِb َhَّllā َّnِiʾ ۚ ِhَmāَyِqْlā َmْwَy āwُlِmَʿع āَmِb mُhُyʾِّbَnُy َّmُht ۖ āwُnāَk āَm َnْyَaʾ ْmُhَʿعَm َwُh āَّlِiʾ َrَhtْkَaʾ āَlَw َkِlَٰhd nِm ٰyَnْdَaʾ āَlَw ْmُhُsِdāَs َwُh āَّlِiʾ ٍhَsْmَhk āَlَw ْmُhُʿعِbāَr َwُh āَّlِiʾ ٍhَhtāَlَht ٰyَwْjgَّn nِm ُnwُkَy āَm ۖ ِḍْrَaʾْlā yِf āَmَw ِtāَwāَmَّslā yِf āَm ُmَlْʿعَy َhَّllā َّnَaʾ َrَt ْmَlَaʾ

footnotes.text: Through His knowledge of them and their secrets.

ayas.translation: ُryِṣَmْlā َsْyʾِbَf ۖ āَhَnْwَlْṣَy ُmَّnَhَjg ْmُhُbْsَḥ ۚ ُlwُqَn āَmِb ُhَّllā āَnُbِّhdَʿعُy āَlْwَl ْmِhِsُfnَaʾ yِf َnwُlwُqَyَw ُhَّllā ِhِb َkِّyَḥُy ْmَl āَmِb َkْwَّyَḥ َkwُءāَjg āَhdِiʾَw ِlwُsَّrlā ِtَyِṣْʿعَmَw ِnāَwْdُʿعْlāَw ِmْhtِiʾْlāِb َnْwَjgāَnَtَyَw ُhْnَʿع āwُhُn āَmِl َnwُdwُʿعَy َّmُht ٰyَwْjgَّnlā ِnَʿع āwُhُn َnyِhdَّlā yَlِiʾ َrَt ْmَlَaʾ

footnotes.text: This is in reference to the Jews who would greet the Muslims with the words "Death be upon you," rather than "Peace."

ayas.translation: َnwُrَhsْḥُt ِhْyَlِiʾ yِhdَّlā َhَّllā āwُqَّtāَw ۖ ٰyَwْqَّtlāَw ِّrِbْlāِb āْwَjgāَnَtَw ِlwُsَّrlā ِtَyِṣْʿعَmَw ِnāَwْdُʿعْlāَw ِmْhtِiʾْlāِb āْwَjgāَnَtَt āَlَf ْmُtْyَjgāَnَt āَhdِiʾ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: The reference may be to the sinful type of conversation, as mentioned in the previous verses, or to the practice of two persons speaking in confidence in the presence of a third, which might lead him to assume that he is the subject of their conversation. Such behavior was prohibited by the Prophet (ﷺ) in narrations of al-Bukhārī and Muslim.

ayas.translation: ٌryِbَhk َnwُlَmْʿعَt āَmِb ُhَّllāَw ۚ ٍtāَjgَrَd َmْlِʿعْlā āwُtwُaʾ َnyِhdَّlāَw ْmُknِm āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā ُhَّllā ِʿعَfْrَy āwُzُhsnāَf āwُzُhsnā َlyِq āَhdِiʾَw ۖ ْmُkَl ُhَّllā ِḥَsْfَy āwُḥَsْfāَf ِsِlāَjgَmْlā yِf āwُḥَّsَfَt ْmُkَl َlyِq āَhdِiʾ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: In His mercy, in Paradise, or in everything good.
To prayer, to battle, or to good deeds.

ayas.translation: ٌmyِḥَّr ٌrwُfَغ َhَّllā َّnِiʾَf āwُdِjgَt ْmَّl nِiʾَf ۚ ُrَhْṭَaʾَw ْmُkَّl ٌrْyَhk َkِlَٰhd ۚ ًhَqَdَṣ ْmُkāَwْjgَn ْyَdَy َnْyَb āwُmِّdَqَf َlwُsَّrlā ُmُtْyَjgāَn āَhdِiʾ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

َnwُlَmْʿعَt āَmِb ٌryِbَhk ُhَّllāَw ۚ ُhَlwُsَrَw َhَّllā āwُʿعyِṭَaʾَw َhāَkَّzlā āwُtāʾَw َhāَlَّṣlā āwُmyِqَaʾَf ْmُkْyَlَʿع ُhَّllā َbāَtَw āwُlَʿعْfَt ْmَl ْhdِiʾَf ۚ ٍtāَqَdَṣ ْmُkāَwْjgَn ْyَdَy َnْyَb āwُmِّdَqُt nَaʾ ْmُtْqَfْhsَaʾَaʾ
َnwُmَlْʿعَy ْmُhَw ِbِhdَkْlā yَlَʿع َnwُfِlْḥَyَw ْmُhْnِm āَlَw ْmُknِّm mُh āَّm mِhْyَlَʿع ُhَّllā َbِḍَغ āًmْwَq āْwَّlَwَt َnyِhdَّlā yَlِiʾ َrَt ْmَlَaʾ

footnotes.text: They assume that their lies will be believed and that they will escape detection as they did in worldly life.

ayas.translation: َnwُḥِlْfُmْlā ُmُh ِhَّllā َbْzِḥ َّnِiʾ āَlَaʾ ۚ ِhَّllā ُbْzِḥ َkِyʾٰـَlwُaʾ ۚ ُhْnَʿع āwُḍَrَw ْmُhْnَʿع ُhَّllā َyِḍَr ۚ āَhyِf َnyِdِlāَhk ُrāَhْnَaʾْlā āَhِtْḥَt nِm yِrْjgَt ٍtāَّnَjg ْmُhُlِhkْdُyَw ۖ ُhْnِّm ٍḥwُrِb mُhَdَّyَaʾَw َnāَmyِiʾْlā ُmِhِbwُlُq yِf َbَtَk َkِyʾٰـَlwُaʾ ۚ ْmُhَtَryِhsَʿع ْwَaʾ ْmُhَnāَwْhkِiʾ ْwَaʾ ْmُhَءāَnْbَaʾ ْwَaʾ ْmُhَءāَbāʾ āwُnāَk ْwَlَw ُhَlwُsَrَw َhَّllā َّdāَḥ ْnَm َnwُّdāَwُy ِrِhkāʾْlā ِmْwَyْlāَw ِhَّllāِb َnwُnِmْwʾُy āًmْwَq ُdِjgَt āَّl

footnotes.text: i.e., "that which gives life," explained as the guidance of the Qur’ān or victory over their opponents.
See footnote to <reference chapter="57" verses="1">57:1</reference>.

ayas.translation: ِrāَṣْbَaʾْlā yِlwُaʾ āَy āwُrِbَtْʿعāَf َnyِnِmْwʾُmْlā yِdْyَaʾَw ْmِhyِdْyَaʾِb mُhَtwُyُb َnwُbِrْhkُy ۚ َbْʿعُّrlā ُmِhِbwُlُq yِf َfَhdَqَw ۖ āwُbِsَtْḥَy ْmَl ُhtْyَḥ ْnِm ُhَّllā ُmُhāَtَaʾَf ِhَّllā َnِّm mُhُnwُṣُḥ ْmُhُtَʿعِnāَّm mُhَّnَaʾ āwُّnَẓَw ۖ āwُjgُrْhkَy nَaʾ ْmُtnَnَẓ āَm ۚ ِrْhsَḥْlā ِlَّwَaʾِl ْmِhِrāَyِd nِm ِbāَtِkْlā ِlْhَaʾ ْnِm āwُrَfَk َnyِhdَّlā َjgَrْhkَaʾ yِhdَّlā َwُh

footnotes.text: Referring to the Jews of Banun-Naḍeer, who broke their pact with the Messenger of Allāh (ﷺ).
This was the first tme they had ever been gathered and expelled.
Meaning that they went through no hardship (i.e., war) to obtain it.

ayas.translation: ِbāَqِʿعْlā ُdyِdَhs َhَّllā َّnِiʾ ۖ َhَّllā āwُqَّtāَw ۚ āwُhَtnāَf ُhْnَʿع ْmُkāَhَn āَmَw ُhwُhdُhkَf ُlwُsَّrlā ُmُkāَtāʾ āَmَw ۚ ْmُknِm ِءāَyِnْغَaʾْlā َnْyَb ًhَlwُd َnwُkَy āَl ْyَk ِlyِbَّslā ِnْbāَw ِnyِkāَsَmْlāَw ٰyَmāَtَyْlāَw ٰyَbْrُqْlā yِhdِlَw ِlwُsَّrlِlَw ِhَّlِlَf ٰyَrُqْlā ِlْhَaʾ ْnِm ِhِlwُsَr ٰyَlَʿع ُhَّllā َءāَfَaʾ āَّm

footnotes.text: Those of Banū Hāshim and Banū Muṭṭalib, whom he (ﷺ) had prohibited from accepting zakāh.

This ruling concerning properties abandoned by an enemy without a war effort differs from that in Sūrah al-Anfāl, <reference chapter="8" verses="41">verse 41</reference>, which refers to spoils of war in which four fifths is distributed among those who fought in Allāh's cause.

ayas.translation: َnwُḥِlْfُmْlā ُmُh َkِyʾٰـَlwُaʾَf ِhِsْfَn َّḥُhs َqwُy nَmَw ۚ ٌhَṣāَṣَhk ْmِhِb َnāَk ْwَlَw ْmِhِsُfnَaʾ ٰyَlَʿع َnwُrِhtْwʾُyَw āwُtwُaʾ āَّmِّm ًhَjgāَḥ ْmِhِrwُdُṣ yِf َnwُdِjgَy āَlَw ْmِhْyَlِiʾ َrَjgāَh ْnَm َnwُّbِḥُy ْmِhِlْbَq nِm َnāَmyِiʾْlāَw َrāَّdlā āwُءَّwَbَt َnyِhdَّlāَw

footnotes.text: Before the settlement of the emigrants (Muhājireen) among the Anṣār, for whom a share is delegated as well.

ayas.translation: ٌmyِḥَّr ٌfwُءَr َkَّnِiʾ āَnَّbَr āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlِّl āًّlِغ āَnِbwُlُq yِf ْlَʿعْjgَt āَlَw ِnāَmyِiʾْlāِb āَnwُqَbَs َnyِhdَّlā āَnِnāَwْhkِiʾِlَw āَnَl ْrِfْغā āَnَّbَr َnwُlwُqَy ْmِhِdْʿعَb nِm āwُءāَjg َnyِhdَّlāَw

َnwُbِhdāَkَl ْmُhَّnِiʾ ُdَhْhsَy ُhَّllāَw ْmُkَّnَrُṣnَnَl ْmُtْlِtwُq nِiʾَw āًdَbَaʾ āًdَḥَaʾ ْmُkyِf ُʿعyِṭُn āَlَw ْmُkَʿعَm َّnَjgُrْhkَnَl ْmُtْjgِrْhkُaʾ ْnِyʾَl ِbāَtِkْlā ِlْhَaʾ ْnِm āwُrَfَk َnyِhdَّlā ُmِhِnāَwْhkِiʾِl َnwُlwُqَy āwُqَfāَn َnyِhdَّlā yَlِiʾ َrَt ْmَlَaʾ
َnwُrَṣnُy āَl َّmُht َrāَbْdَaʾْlā َّnُّlَwُyَl ْmُhwُrَṣَّn nِyʾَlَw ْmُhَnwُrُṣnَy āَl āwُlِtwُq nِyʾَlَw ْmُhَʿعَm َnwُjgُrْhkَy āَl āwُjgِrْhkُaʾ ْnِyʾَl

َnwُlِqْʿعَy āَّl ٌmْwَq ْmُhَّnَaʾِb َkِlَٰhd ۚ ٰyَّtَhs ْmُhُbwُlُqَw āًʿعyِmَjg ْmُhُbَsْḥَt ۚ ٌdyِdَhs ْmُhَnْyَb mُhُsْaʾَb ۚ ٍrُdُjg ِءāَrَw nِm ْwَaʾ ٍhَnَّṣَḥُّm yًrُq yِf āَّlِiʾ āًʿعyِmَjg ْmُkَnwُlِtāَqُy āَl
َnwُlَmْʿعَt āَmِb ٌryِbَhk َhَّllā َّnِiʾ ۚ َhَّllā āwُqَّtāَw ۖ ٍdَغِl ْtَmَّdَq āَّm ٌsْfَn ْrُẓnَtْlَw َhَّllā āwُqَّtā āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: See footnotes to <reference chapter="6" verses="73">6:73</reference>.
And owner of everything in existence.
i.e., transcendent above any aspect belonging to His creation. Also, the possessor and grantor of blessings.
Literally, "Free" from any imperfection. Also, "Peace" or "Soundness."
And safety, i.e., reassurance that His promise is always fulfilled. Also, He who bestows faith.
i.e., who observes, guards and protects. Also, "the Criterion."
Refer to footnote in <reference chapter="2" verses="129">2:129</reference>.

Whose irresistible force is without limitation; the one above all things who compels the creation to be as He wills it. Also, "the Amender" or "the Rectifier" who repairs, restores, completes or sets something right once again, out of His mercy.
Supreme, complete and perfect in His essence, attributes and actions.
i.e., He who destined existence for His creation.
i.e., He who brings His creation into existence.
i.e., He who gives every creation its particular form.
Refer to the final paragraphs of the "Introduction" for a brief discussion of these attributes.
Refer to footnote in <reference chapter="6" verses="18">6:18</reference>.

ayas.translation: ِlyِbَّslā َءāَwَs َّlَḍ ْdَqَf ْmُknِm ُhْlَʿعْfَy nَmَw ۚ ْmُtnَlْʿعَaʾ āَmَw ْmُtْyَfْhkَaʾ āَmِb ُmَlْʿعَaʾ āَnَaʾَw ِhَّdَwَmْlāِb mِhْyَlِiʾ َnwُّrِsُt ۚ yِtāَḍْrَm َءāَغِtْbāَw yِlyِbَs yِf āًdāَhِjg ْmُtْjgَrَhk ْmُtnُk nِiʾ ْmُkِّbَr ِhَّllāِb āwُnِmْwʾُt nَaʾ ۙ ْmُkāَّyِiʾَw َlwُsَّrlā َnwُjgِrْhkُy ِّqَḥْlā َnِّm mُkَءāَjg āَmِb āwُrَfَk ْdَqَw ِhَّdَwَmْlāِb mِhْyَlِiʾ َnwُqْlُt َءāَyِlْwَaʾ ْmُkَّwُdَʿعَw yِّwُdَʿع āwُhdِhkَّtَt āَl āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy ِmyِḥَّrlā ِnٰـَmْḥَّrlā ِhَّllā ِmْsِb

footnotes.text: i.e., close associates and friends.

ayas.translation: ُryِṣَmْlā َkْyَlِiʾَw āَnْbَnَaʾ َkْyَlِiʾَw āَnْlَّkَwَt َkْyَlَʿع āَnَّbَّr ۖ ٍءْyَhs nِm ِhَّllā َnِm َkَl ُkِlْmَaʾ āَmَw َkَl َّnَrِfْغَtْsَaʾَl ِhyِbَaʾِl َmyِhāَrْbِiʾ َlْwَq āَّlِiʾ ُhَdْḥَw ِhَّllāِb āwُnِmْwʾُt ٰyَّtَḥ āًdَbَaʾ ُءāَḍْغَbْlāَw ُhَwāَdَʿعْlā ُmُkَnْyَbَw āَnَnْyَb āَdَbَw ْmُkِb āَnْrَfَk ِhَّllā ِnwُd nِm َnwُdُbْʿعَt āَّmِmَw ْmُknِm ُءāʾَrُb āَّnِiʾ ْmِhِmْwَqِl āwُlāَq ْhdِiʾ ُhَʿعَm َnyِhdَّlāَw َmyِhāَrْbِiʾ yِf ٌhَnَsَḥ ٌhَwْsُaʾ ْmُkَl ْtَnāَk ْdَq

footnotes.text: An example to be followed.

ayas.translation: ُmyِkَḥْlā ُzyِzَʿعْlā َtnَaʾ َkَّnِiʾ ۖ āَnَّbَr āَnَl ْrِfْغāَw āwُrَfَk َnyِhdَّlِّl ًhَnْtِf āَnْlَʿعْjgَt āَl āَnَّbَr

footnotes.text: To accomplish this or whatever He should will.

ayas.translation: َnyِṭِsْqُmْlā ُّbِḥُy َhَّllā َّnِiʾ ۚ ْmِhْyَlِiʾ āwُṭِsْqُtَw ْmُhwُّrَbَt nَaʾ ْmُkِrāَyِd nِّm mُkwُjgِrْhkُy ْmَlَw ِnyِّdlā yِf ْmُkwُlِtāَqُy ْmَl َnyِhdَّlā ِnَʿع ُhَّllā ُmُkāَhْnَy āَّl

َnwُmِlāَّẓlā ُmُh َkِyʾٰـَlwُaʾَf ْmُhَّlَwَtَy nَmَw ۚ ْmُhْwَّlَwَt nَaʾ ْmُkِjgāَrْhkِiʾ ٰyَlَʿع āwُrَhāَẓَw ْmُkِrāَyِd nِّm mُkwُjgَrْhkَaʾَw ِnyِّdlā yِf ْmُkwُlَtāَq َnyِhdَّlā ِnَʿع ُhَّllā ُmُkāَhْnَy āَmَّnِiʾ

footnotes.text: See footnote to <reference chapter="60" verses="1">verse 1</reference> of this sūrah.

ayas.translation: ٌmyِkَḥ ٌmyِlَʿع ُhَّllāَw ۚ ْmُkَnْyَb ُmُkْḥَy ۖ ِhَّllā ُmْkُḥ ْmُkِlَٰhd ۚ āwُqَfnَaʾ āَm āwُlَaʾْsَyْlَw ْmُtْqَfnَaʾ āَm āwُlَaʾْsāَw ِrِfāَwَkْlā ِmَṣِʿعِb āwُkِsْmُt āَlَw ۚ َّnُhَrwُjgُaʾ َّnُhwُmُtْyَtāʾ āَhdِiʾ َّnُhwُḥِknَt nَaʾ ْmُkْyَlَʿع َḥāَnُjg āَlَw ۚ āwُqَfnَaʾ āَّm mُhwُtāʾَw ۖ َّnُhَl َnwُّlِḥَy ْmُh āَlَw ْmُhَّl ٌّlِḥ َّnُh āَl ۖ ِrāَّfُkْlā yَlِiʾ َّnُhwُʿعِjgْrَt āَlَf ٍtāَnِmْwʾُm َّnُhwُmُtْmِlَʿع ْnِiʾَf ۖ َّnِhِnāَmyِiʾِb ُmَlْʿعَaʾ ُhَّllā ۖ َّnُhwُnِḥَtْmāَf ٍtāَrِjgāَhُm ُtāَnِmْwʾُmْlā ُmُkَءāَjg āَhdِiʾ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: For marriage, i.e., compensate their loss.

When a disbelieving wife chose to join the disbelievers, a Muslim husband could demand in return the equivalent of her mahr. Likewise, the disbelievers had a similar right when a believing woman joined the Muslims. This and the following verses were revealed subsequent to the Treaty of al-Ḥudaybiyyah.

ayas.translation: َnwُnِmْwʾُm ِhِb mُtnَaʾ yِhdَّlā َhَّllā āwُqَّtāَw ۚ āwُqَfnَaʾ āَm َlْhtِّm mُhُjgāَwْzَaʾ ْtَbَhَhd َnyِhdَّlā āwُtāʾَf ْmُtْbَqāَʿعَf ِrāَّfُkْlā yَlِiʾ ْmُkِjgāَwْzَaʾ ْnِّm ٌءْyَhs ْmُkَtāَf nِiʾَw

footnotes.text: From the side of the disbelievers, i.e., war booty or a believing woman seeking refuge with the Muslims.

ayas.translation: ٌmyِḥَّr ٌrwُfَغ َhَّllā َّnِiʾ ۖ َhَّllā َّnُhَl ْrِfْغَtْsāَw َّnُhْʿعِyāَbَf ۙ ٍfwُrْʿعَm yِf َkَnyِṣْʿعَy āَlَw َّnِhِlُjgْrَaʾَw َّnِhyِdْyَaʾ َnْyَb ُhَnyِrَtْfَy ٍnāَtْhُbِb َnyِtْaʾَy āَlَw َّnُhَdāَlْwَaʾ َnْlُtْqَy āَlَw َnyِnْzَy āَlَw َnْqِrْsَy āَlَw āًyʾْyَhs ِhَّllāِb َnْkِrْhsُy āَّl nَaʾ ٰyَlَʿع َkَnْʿعِyāَbُy ُtāَnِmْwʾُmْlā َkَءāَjg āَhdِiʾ ُّyِbَّnlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: This is an allusion to pregnancy and childbirth, i.e., to falsely attribute a child (whether adopted or born of adultery) to a woman's husband.

ayas.translation: ِrwُbُqْlā ِbāَḥْṣَaʾ ْnِm ُrāَّfُkْlā َsِyʾَy āَmَk ِhَrِhkāʾْlā َnِm āwُsِyʾَy ْdَq ْmِhْyَlَʿع ُhَّllā َbِḍَغ āًmْwَq āْwَّlَwَtَt āَl āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: See footnote to <reference chapter="57" verses="1">57:1</reference>.

ayas.translation: َnyِqِsāَfْlā َmْwَqْlā yِdْhَy āَl ُhَّllāَw ۚ ْmُhَbwُlُq ُhَّllā َغāَzَaʾ āwُغāَz āَّmَlَf ۖ ْmُkْyَlِiʾ ِhَّllā ُlwُsَr yِّnَaʾ َnwُmَlْʿعَّt dَqَw yِnَnwُhdْwʾُt َmِl ِmْwَq āَy ِhِmْwَqِl ٰyَswُm َlāَq ْhdِiʾَw

ٌnyِbُّm ٌrْḥِs āَhdٰـَh āwُlāَq ِtāَnِّyَbْlāِb mُhَءāَjg āَّmَlَf ۖ ُdَmْḥَaʾ ُhُmْsā yِdْʿعَb nِm yِtْaʾَy ٍlwُsَrِb āًrِّhsَbُmَw ِhāَrْwَّtlā َnِm َّyَdَy َnْyَb āَmِّl āًqِّdَṣُّm mُkْyَlِiʾ ِhَّllā ُlwُsَr yِّnِiʾ َlyِyʾāَrْsِiʾ yِnَb āَy َmَyْrَm ُnْbā yَsyِʿع َlāَq ْhdِiʾَw

footnotes.text: Another name of Prophet Muḥammad (ﷺ).
i.e., fraud or deception.

ayas.translation: َnyِrِhāَẓ āwُḥَbْṣَaʾَf ْmِhِّwُdَʿع ٰyَlَʿع āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَnْdَّyَaʾَf ۖ ٌhَfِyʾāَّṭ tَrَfَkَw َlyِyʾāَrْsِiʾ yِnَb nِّm ٌhَfِyʾāَّṭ tَnَmāʾَf ۖ ِhَّllā ُrāَṣnَaʾ ُnْḥَn َnwُّyِrāَwَḥْlā َlāَq ۖ ِhَّllā yَlِiʾ yِrāَṣnَaʾ ْnَm َnyِّyِrāَwَḥْlِl َmَyْrَm ُnْbā yَsyِʿع َlāَq āَmَk ِhَّllā َrāَṣnَaʾ āwُnwُk āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: See footnote to <reference chapter="57" verses="1">57:1</reference>.
Refer to footnote in <reference chapter="6" verses="18">6:18</reference>.

ayas.translation: ٍnyِbُّm ٍlāَlَḍ yِfَl ُlْbَq nِm āwُnāَk nِiʾَw َhَmْkِḥْlāَw َbāَtِkْlā ُmُhُmِّlَʿعُyَw ْmِhyِّkَzُyَw ِhِtāَyāʾ ْmِhْyَlَʿع wُlْtَy ْmُhْnِّm āًlwُsَr َnyِّyِّmُaʾْlā yِf َhtَʿعَb yِhdَّlā َwُh

َnyِmِlāَّẓlā َmْwَqْlā yِdْhَy āَl ُhَّllāَw ۚ ِhَّllā ِtāَyāʾِb āwُbَّhdَk َnyِhdَّlā ِmْwَqْlā ُlَhtَm َsْyʾِb ۚ āًrāَfْsَaʾ ُlِmْḥَy ِrāَmِḥْlā ِlَhtَmَk āَhwُlِmْḥَy ْmَl َّmُht َhāَrْwَّtlā āwُlِّmُḥ َnyِhdَّlā ُlَhtَm

footnotes.text: i.e., neglected their responsibility towards it by not putting its teachings into practice.
But does not benefit from their contents.

ayas.translation: َnyِqِdāَṣ ْmُtnُk nِiʾ َtْwَmْlā āُwَّnَmَtَf ِsāَّnlā ِnwُd nِm ِhَّlِl ُءāَyِlْwَaʾ ْmُkَّnَaʾ ْmُtْmَʿعَz nِiʾ āwُdāَh َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy ْlُq
َnwُmَlْʿعَt ْmُtnُk nِiʾ ْmُkَّl ٌrْyَhk ْmُkِlَٰhd ۚ َʿعْyَbْlā āwُrَhdَw ِhَّllā ِrْkِhd ٰyَlِiʾ āْwَʿعْsāَf ِhَʿعُmُjgْlā ِmْwَy nِm ِhāَlَّṣlِl َyِdwُn āَhdِiʾ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy
َnwُḥِlْfُt ْmُkَّlَʿعَّl āًryِhtَk َhَّllā āwُrُkْhdāَw ِhَّllā ِlْḍَf nِm āwُغَtْbāَw ِḍْrَaʾْlā yِf āwُrِhsَtnāَf ُhāَlَّṣlā ِtَyِḍُq āَhdِiʾَf
َnyِqِzāَّrlā ُrْyَhk ُhَّllāَw ۚ ِhَrāَjgِّtlā َnِmَw ِwْhَّllā َnِّm ٌrْyَhk ِhَّllā َdnِʿع āَm ْlُq ۚ āًmِyʾāَq َkwُkَrَtَw āَhْyَlِiʾ āwُّḍَfnā āًwْhَl ْwَaʾ ًhَrāَjgِt āْwَaʾَr āَhdِiʾَw

footnotes.text: i.e., bodies with empty minds and empty hearts.

ayas.translation: َnwُrِsāَhkْlā ُmُh َkِyʾٰـَlwُaʾَf َkِlَٰhd ْlَʿعْfَy nَmَw ۚ ِhَّllā ِrْkِhd nَʿع ْmُkُdāَlْwَaʾ āَlَw ْmُkُlāَwْmَaʾ ْmُkِhْlُt āَl āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy
َnyِḥِlāَّṣlā َnِّm nُkَaʾَw َqَّdَّṣَaʾَf ٍbyِrَq ٍlَjgَaʾ ٰyَlِiʾ yِnَtْrَّhkَaʾ āَlْwَl ِّbَr َlwُqَyَf ُtْwَmْlā ُmُkَdَḥَaʾ َyِtْaʾَy nَaʾ ِlْbَq nِّm mُkāَnْqَzَr āَّm nِm āwُqِfnَaʾَw

footnotes.text: See footnote to <reference chapter="57" verses="1">57:1</reference>.

ayas.translation: ٌdyِmَḥ ٌّyِnَغ ُhَّllāَw ۚ ُhَّllā yَnْغَtْsāَّw ۚ āwَّlَwَtَw āwُrَfَkَf āَnَnwُdْhَy ٌrَhsَbَaʾ āwُlāَqَf ِtāَnِّyَbْlāِb mُhُlُsُr ْmِhyِtْaʾَّt tَnāَk ُhَّnَaʾِb َkِlَٰhd
ٌryِsَy ِhَّllā yَlَʿع َkِlَٰhdَw ۚ ْmُtْlِmَʿع āَmِb َّnُwʾَّbَnُtَl َّmُht َّnُhtَʿعْbُtَl yِّbَrَw ٰyَlَb ْlُq ۚ āwُhtَʿعْbُy nَّl nَaʾ āwُrَfَk َnyِhdَّlā َmَʿعَz

ُmyِẓَʿعْlā ُzْwَfْlā َkِlَٰhd ۚ āًdَbَaʾ āَhyِf َnyِdِlāَhk ُrāَhْnَaʾْlā āَhِtْḥَt nِm yِrْjgَt ٍtāَّnَjg ُhْlِhkْdُyَw ِhِtāَyʾِّyَs ُhْnَʿع ْrِّfَkُy āًḥِlāَṣ ْlَmْʿعَyَw ِhَّllāِb nِmْwʾُy nَmَw ۗ ِnُbāَغَّtlā ُmْwَy َkِlَٰhd ۖ ِʿعْmَjgْlā ِmْwَyِl ْmُkُʿعَmْjgَy َmْwَy

footnotes.text: "At-Taghābun" suggests having been outdone by others in the acquisition of something valued. That Day, the disbelievers will suffer the loss of Paradise to the believers.

ayas.translation: ٌmyِḥَّr ٌrwُfَغ َhَّllā َّnِiʾَf āwُrِfْغَtَw āwُḥَfْṣَtَw āwُfْʿعَt nِiʾَw ۚ ْmُhwُrَhdْḥāَf ْmُkَّl āًّwُdَʿع ْmُkِdāَlْwَaʾَw ْmُkِjgāَwْzَaʾ ْnِm َّnِiʾ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy
َnwُḥِlْfُmْlā ُmُh َkِyʾٰـَlwُaʾَf ِhِsْfَn َّḥُhs َqwُy nَmَw ۗ ْmُkِsُfnَaʾِّl āًrْyَhk āwُqِfnَaʾَw āwُʿعyِṭَaʾَw āwُʿعَmْsāَw ْmُtْʿعَṭَtْsā āَm َhَّllā āwُqَّtāَf

footnotes.text: Who gives much in return for little.
Refer to footnote in <reference chapter="2" verses="225">2:225</reference>.

ayas.translation: āًrْmَaʾ َkِlَٰhd َdْʿعَb ُhtِdْḥُy َhَّllā َّlَʿعَl yِrْdَt āَl ۚ ُhَsْfَn َmَlَẓ ْdَqَf ِhَّllā َdwُdُḥ َّdَʿعَtَy nَmَw ۚ ِhَّllā ُdwُdُḥ َkْlِtَw ۚ ٍhَnِّyَbُّm ٍhَhsِḥāَfِb َnyِtْaʾَy nَaʾ āَّlِiʾ َnْjgُrْhkَy āَlَw َّnِhِtwُyُb nِm َّnُhwُjgِrْhkُt āَl ۖ ْmُkَّbَr َhَّllā āwُqَّtāَw ۖ َhَّdِʿعْlā āwُṣْḥَaʾَw َّnِhِtَّdِʿعِl َّnُhwُqِّlَṭَf َءāَsِّnlā ُmُtْqَّlَṭ āَhdِiʾ ُّyِbَّnlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy ِmyِḥَّrlā ِnٰـَmْḥَّrlā ِhَّllā ِmْsِb

footnotes.text: See rulings in <reference chapter="2" verses="228-233">2:228-233</reference>. A wife should not be divorced except after the completion of her menstrual period but before sexual intercourse has occurred, or else during a confirmed pregnancy. The pronouncement of divorce begins her waiting period (ʿiddah).
Such as regret or renewed desire for the wife.

ayas.translation: āًjgَrْhkَm ُhَّl lَʿعْjgَy َhَّllā ِqَّtَy nَmَw ۚ ِrِhkāʾْlā ِmْwَyْlāَw ِhَّllāِb ُnِmْwʾُy َnāَk nَm ِhِb ُẓَʿعwُy ْmُkِlَٰhd ۚ ِhَّlِl َhَdāَhَّhslā āwُmyِqَaʾَw ْmُknِّm ٍlْdَʿع ْyَwَhd āwُdِhْhsَaʾَw ٍfwُrْʿعَmِb َّnُhwُqِrāَf ْwَaʾ ٍfwُrْʿعَmِb َّnُhwُkِsْmَaʾَf َّnُhَlَjgَaʾ َnْغَlَb āَhdِiʾَf

footnotes.text: i.e., relief from distress.

ayas.translation: āًrْsُy ِhِrْmَaʾ ْnِm ُhَّl lَʿعْjgَy َhَّllā ِqَّtَy nَmَw ۚ َّnُhَlْmَḥ َnْʿعَḍَy nَaʾ َّnُhُlَjgَaʾ ِlāَmْḥَaʾْlā ُtāَlwُaʾَw ۚ َnْḍِḥَy ْmَl yِyʾāَّllāَw ٍrُhْhsَaʾ ُhَhtāَlَht َّnُhُtَّdِʿعَf ْmُtْbَtْrā ِnِiʾ ْmُkِyʾāَsِّn nِm ِḍyِḥَmْlā َnِm َnْsِyʾَy yِyʾāَّllāَw

footnotes.text: The ruling concerning pregnancy applies also in the case of the husband's death.

ayas.translation: ٰyَrْhkُaʾ ُhَl ُʿعِḍْrُtَsَf ْmُtْrَsāَʿعَt nِiʾَw ۖ ٍfwُrْʿعَmِb mُkَnْyَb āwُrِmَtْaʾَw ۖ َّnُhَrwُjgُaʾ َّnُhwُtāʾَf ْmُkَl َnْʿعَḍْrَaʾ ْnِiʾَf ۚ َّnُhَlْmَḥ َnْʿعَḍَy ٰyَّtَḥ َّnِhْyَlَʿع āwُqِfnَaʾَf ٍlْmَḥ ِtāَlwُaʾ َّnُk nِiʾَw ۚ َّnِhْyَlَʿع āwُqِّyَḍُtِl َّnُhwُّrāَḍُt āَlَw ْmُkِdْjgُw nِّm mُtnَkَs ُhtْyَḥ ْnِm َّnُhwُnِkْsَaʾ

footnotes.text: During their waiting period (referring to wives whose divorce has been pronounced).
So that they would be forced to leave or to ransom themselves.
See <reference chapter="2" verses="233">2:233</reference>.

ayas.translation: āًrْsُy ٍrْsُʿع َdْʿعَb ُhَّllā ُlَʿعْjgَyَs ۚ āَhāَtāʾ āَm āَّlِiʾ āًsْfَn ُhَّllā ُfِّlَkُy āَl ۚ ُhَّllā ُhāَtāʾ āَّmِm ْqِfnُyْlَf ُhُqْzِr ِhْyَlَʿع َrِdُq nَmَw ۖ ِhِtَʿعَs nِّm ٍhَʿعَs wُhd ْqِfnُyِl
āًrْkُّn āًbāَhdَʿع āَhāَnْbَّhdَʿعَw āًdyِdَhs āًbāَsِḥ āَhāَnْbَsāَḥَf ِhِlُsُrَw āَhِّbَr ِrْmَaʾ ْnَʿع ْtَtَʿع ٍhَyْrَq nِّm nِّyَaʾَkَw
āًrْkِhd ْmُkْyَlِiʾ ُhَّllā َlَznَaʾ ْdَq ۚ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā ِbāَbْlَaʾْlā yِlwُaʾ āَy َhَّllā āwُqَّtāَf ۖ āًdyِdَhs āًbāَhdَʿع ْmُhَl ُhَّllā َّdَʿعَaʾ

footnotes.text: Some scholars have interpreted "dhikr" here as "a reminder," meaning the Messenger (ﷺ), since he is mentioned in the following verse.

ayas.translation: āًqْzِr ُhَl ُhَّllā َnَsْḥَaʾ ْdَq ۖ āًdَbَaʾ āَhyِf َnyِdِlāَhk ُrāَhْnَaʾْlā āَhِtْḥَt nِm yِrْjgَt ٍtāَّnَjg ُhْlِhkْdُy āًḥِlāَṣ ْlَmْʿعَyَw ِhَّllāِb nِmْwʾُy nَmَw ۚ ِrwُّnlā yَlِiʾ ِtāَmُlُّẓlā َnِm ِtāَḥِlāَّṣlā āwُlِmَʿعَw āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā َjgِrْhkُyِّl ٍtāَnِّyَbُm ِhَّllā ِtāَyāʾ ْmُkْyَlَʿع wُlْtَy āًlwُsَّr

footnotes.text: i.e., a similar number: seven.

By means of a kaffārah (expiation). This is required when one is unable to fulfill an oath or when one has taken an oath which would not be pleasing to Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā). See <reference chapter="5" verses="89">5:89</reference>.

ayas.translation: ُryِbَhkْlā ُmyِlَʿعْlā َyِnَaʾَّbَn َlāَq ۖ āَhdٰـَh َkَaʾَbnَaʾ ْnَm ْtَlāَq ِhِb āَhَaʾَّbَn āَّmَlَf ۖ ٍḍْʿعَb nَʿع َḍَrْʿعَaʾَw ُhَḍْʿعَb َfَّrَʿع ِhْyَlَʿع ُhَّllā ُhَrَhْẓَaʾَw ِhِb ْtَaʾَّbَn āَّmَlَf āًhtyِdَḥ ِhِjgāَwْzَaʾ ِḍْʿعَb ٰyَlِiʾ ُّyِbَّnlā َّrَsَaʾ ْhdِiʾَw

ٌryِhَẓ َkِlَٰhd َdْʿعَb ُhَkِyʾāَlَmْlāَw ۖ َnyِnِmْwʾُmْlā ُḥِlāَṣَw ُlyِrْbِjgَw ُhāَlْwَm َwُh َhَّllā َّnِiʾَf ِhْyَlَʿع āَrَhāَẓَt nِiʾَw ۖ āَmُkُbwُlُq ْtَغَṣ ْdَqَf ِhَّllā yَlِiʾ āَbwُtَt nِiʾ

footnotes.text: Emigrating for the cause of Allāh. Another meaning is "given to fasting."

ayas.translation: َnwُrَmْwʾُy āَm َnwُlَʿعْfَyَw ْmُhَrَmَaʾ āَm َhَّllā َnwُṣْʿعَy āَّl ٌdāَdِhs ٌẓāَlِغ ٌhَkِyʾāَlَm āَhْyَlَʿع ُhَrāَjgِḥْlāَw ُsāَّnlā āَhُdwُqَw āًrāَn ْmُkyِlْhَaʾَw ْmُkَsُfnَaʾ āwُq āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy
َnwُlَmْʿعَt ْmُtnُk āَm َnْwَzْjgُt āَmَّnِiʾ ۖ َmْwَyْlā āwُrِhdَtْʿعَt āَl āwُrَfَk َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

ٌryِdَq ٍءْyَhs ِّlُk ٰyَlَʿع َkَّnِiʾ ۖ āَnَl ْrِfْغāَw āَnَrwُn āَnَl ْmِmْtَaʾ āَnَّbَr َnwُlwُqَy ْmِhِnāَmْyَaʾِbَw ْmِhyِdْyَaʾ َnْyَb ٰyَʿعْsَy ْmُhُrwُn ۖ ُhَʿعَm āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlāَw َّyِbَّnlā ُhَّllā yِzْhkُy āَl َmْwَy ُrāَhْnَaʾْlā āَhِtْḥَt nِm yِrْjgَt ٍtāَّnَjg ْmُkَlِhkْdُyَw ْmُkِtāَyʾِّyَs ْmُknَʿع َrِّfَkُy nَaʾ ْmُkُّbَr ٰyَsَʿع āًḥwُṣَّn ًhَbْwَt ِhَّllā yَlِiʾ āwُbwُt āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā āَhُّyَaʾ āَy

footnotes.text: i.e., it is expected or promised.

ayas.translation: َnyِlِhkāَّdlā َʿعَm َrāَّnlā āَlُhkْdā َlyِqَw āًyʾْyَhs ِhَّllā َnِm āَmُhْnَʿع āَyِnْغُy ْmَlَf āَmُhāَtَnāَhkَf ِnْyَḥِlāَṣ āَnِdāَbِʿع ْnِm ِnْyَdْbَʿع َtْḥَt āَtَnāَk ۖ ٍṭwُl َtَaʾَrْmāَw ٍḥwُn َtَaʾَrْmā āwُrَfَk َnyِhdَّlِّl āًlَhtَm ُhَّllā َbَrَḍ

footnotes.text: In the matter of religion.

ayas.translation: َnyِmِlāَّẓlā ِmْwَqْlā َnِm yِnِّjgَnَw ِhِlَmَʿعَw َnْwَʿعْrِf nِm yِnِّjgَnَw ِhَّnَjgْlā yِf āًtْyَb َkَdnِʿع yِl ِnْbā ِّbَr ْtَlāَq ْhdِiʾ َnْwَʿعْrِf َtَaʾَrْmā āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlِّl āًlَhtَm ُhَّllā َbَrَḍَw
َnyِtِnāَqْlā َnِm ْtَnāَkَw ِhِbُtُkَw āَhِّbَr ِtāَmِlَkِb ْtَqَّdَṣَw āَnِḥwُّr nِm ِhyِf āَnْhkَfَnَf āَhَjgْrَf ْtَnَṣْḥَaʾ yِtَّlā َnāَrْmِʿع َtَnْbā َmَyْrَmَw
ٍrwُṭُf nِm ٰyَrَt ْlَh َrَṣَbْlā ِʿعِjgْrāَf ۖ ٍtُwāَfَt nِm ِnٰـَmْḥَّrlā ِqْlَhk yِf ٰyَrَt āَّm ۖ āًqāَbِṭ ٍtāَwāَmَs َʿعْbَs َqَlَhk yِhdَّlā

footnotes.text: i.e., one covering or fitting over the other.
i.e., repeatedly.
Thereby driving them from the heavens and preventing them from eavesdropping. See <reference chapter="72" verses="8-9">72:8-9</reference>.

ayas.translation: ُrwُfَt َyِhَw āًqyِhَhs āَhَl āwُʿعِmَs āَhyِf āwُqْlُaʾ āَhdِiʾ
ٍryِbَk ٍlāَlَḍ yِf āَّlِiʾ ْmُtnَaʾ ْnِiʾ ٍءْyَhs nِm ُhَّllā َlَّzَn āَm āَnْlُqَw āَnْbَّhdَkَf ٌryِhdَn āَnَءāَjg ْdَq ٰyَlَb āwُlāَq

footnotes.text: From all good and from Allāh's mercy.
Another accepted meaning is "Does He not know those whom He created...?"

ayas.translation: ُrwُhsُّnlā ِhْyَlِiʾَw ۖ ِhِqْzِّr nِm āwُlُkَw āَhِbِkāَnَm yِf āwُhsْmāَf āًlwُlَhd َḍْrَaʾْlā ُmُkَl َlَʿعَjg yِhdَّlā َwُh

footnotes.text: i.e., stable and subservient.
Literally, "in ascendancy" or "over the heaven."
In a circular motion, as in an earthquake.

ayas.translation: ٍrwُrُغ yِf āَّlِiʾ َnwُrِfāَkْlā ِnِiʾ ۚ ِnٰـَmْḥَّrlā ِnwُd nِّm mُkُrُṣnَy ْmُkَّl ٌdnُjg َwُh yِhdَّlā āَhdٰـَh ْnَّmَaʾ
ٍmyِqَtْsُّm ٍṭāَrِṣ ٰyَlَʿع āًّyِwَs yِhsْmَy nَّmَaʾ ٰyَdْhَaʾ ِhِhْjgَw ٰyَlَʿع āًّbِkُm yِhsْmَy nَmَfَaʾ

footnotes.text: The punishment of which they were warned.
When they challenged their prophets, saying, "Bring on the punishment, if you are truthful."
i.e., inform me.
See footnote to <reference chapter="2" verses="1">2:1</reference>.

i.e., claiming a particular lineage falsely. The description given in these verses is of al-Waleed bin al-Mugheerah (see also <reference chapter="74" verses="11-25">74:11-25</reference>) or possibly, as asserted by Ibn Katheer, al-Akhnas bin Shurayq.
Literally, "trunk," meaning the nose of an elephant or pig.
i.e., without conceding that nothing can be accomplished unless Allāh wills, saying, "...if Allāh wills" ("in-shā’-Allāh"). See <reference chapter="18" verses="23-24">18:23-24</reference>.
To carry out their plan, confident of their ability.
i.e., remember or mention Him by saying, "...if Allāh wills." An additional meaning is "praise" or "thank" Him for His bounty.

ayas.translation: َnwُbِغāَr āَnِّbَr ٰyَlِiʾ āَّnِiʾ āَhْnِّm āًrْyَhk āَnَlِdْbُy nَaʾ āَnُّbَr ٰyَsَʿع

footnotes.text: Of His mercy, forgiveness and bounty.
i.e., those to whom they attribute divinity other than Allāh or partners from among themselves.

i.e., when everyone will find before him great difficulty. In accordance with authentic ḥadīths, "the shin" might also refer to that of Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā), before which every believer will prostrate on the Day of Judgement. See footnote to <reference chapter="2" verses="19">2:19</reference>.
During worldly life.
Allāh will increase His favors to them in this world by way of trial, whereby they will sink deeper into sin and thus into destruction.
But instead, Allāh accepted his repentance and provided means for his recovery. See <reference chapter="37" verses="139-148">37:139-148</reference>.
Or "cold."
Those to which Lot was sent (see <reference chapter="11" verses="82-83">11:82-83</reference>) or generally, all cities which were destroyed due to their denial of a messenger from Allāh.
Which was constructed by Noah.
i.e., weak, enfeebled and unstable.
i.e., any person or any secret you might attempt to conceal.
Literally, "advanced" in anticipation of reward in the Hereafter.
i.e., ending life rather than being the gateway to eternal life.
i.e., I have no valid excuse to stand on.
Another interpretation is "by [Our] right hand," i.e., Allāh would have exacted revenge with might and power.
Causing immediate death.
In the Hereafter. Disbelievers had challenged the Prophet (ﷺ) by invoking Allāh to bring on His punishment. See <reference chapter="8" verses="32">8:32</reference>.
Or "molten metal."
i.e., in the process of disintegration.
An emphatic refusal meaning "It is not to be."
This refers to the skin of the head or of the body or to the body extremities - which will be burned away.
i.e., a specified share, meaning the obligatory zakāh.
i.e., female slaves.
In Paradise.
They sat at a distance in order to oppose and mock the Prophet (ﷺ), claiming that they would enter Paradise before the believers.
i.e., a liquid disdained. So how can they expect to enter Paradise except by the will of their Creator?
i.e., Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā), who determines the point at which the sun, moon and stars rise and set according to season and every position of observation.
i.e., just as they used to race, whenever an idol was newly appointed, to be the first of its worshippers.

ayas.translation: āًrāَbْkِtْsā āwُrَbْkَtْsāَw āwُّrَṣَaʾَw ْmُhَbāَyِht āْwَhsْغَtْsāَw ْmِhِnāَhdāʾ yِf ْmُhَʿعِbāَṣَaʾ āwُlَʿعَjg ْmُhَl َrِfْغَtِl ْmُhُtْwَʿعَd āَmَّlُk yِّnِiʾَw

footnotes.text: Refusing to look or listen.

i.e., in various progressive states and conditions. See also <reference chapter="22" verses="5">22:5</reference> and <reference chapter="23" verses="12-14">23:12-14</reference> in reference to development of the embryo.
See footnote to <reference chapter="67" verses="3">67:3</reference>.

ayas.translation: āًrْsَnَw َqwُʿعَyَw َhtwُغَy āَlَw āًʿعāَwُs āَlَw āًّdَw َّnُrَhdَt āَlَw ْmُkَtَhِlāʾ َّnُrَhdَt āَl āwُlāَqَw

footnotes.text: These were the names of specific idols named after pious men of earlier generations.

ayas.translation: āًrāَṣnَaʾ ِhَّllā ِnwُd nِّm mُhَl āwُdِjgَy ْmَlَf āًrāَn āwُlِhkْdُaʾَf āwُqِrْغُaʾ ْmِhِtāَyʾyِṭَhk āَّmِّm
āًrāَّfَk āًrِjgāَf āَّlِiʾ āwُdِlَy āَlَw َkَdāَbِʿع āwُّlِḍُy ْmُhْrَhdَt nِiʾ َkَّnِiʾ
āًrāَbَt āَّlِiʾ َnyِmِlāَّẓlā ِdِzَt āَlَw ِtāَnِmْwʾُmْlāَw َnyِnِmْwʾُmْlِlَw āًnِmْwʾُm َyِtْyَb َlَhkَd nَmِlَw َّyَdِlāَwِlَw yِl ْrِfْغā ِّbَّr
āًdَḥَaʾ āَnِّbَrِb َkِrْhsُّn nَlَw ۖ ِhِb āَّnَmāʾَf ِdْhsُّrlā yَlِiʾ yِdْhَy

footnotes.text: A plural form may also be understood, i.e., "the foolish ones among us."

ayas.translation: āًbِhdَk ِhَّllā yَlَʿع ُّnِjgْlāَw ُsnِiʾْlā َlwُqَt nَّl nَaʾ āَّnَnَẓ āَّnَaʾَw
āًbُhُhsَw āًdyِdَhs āًsَrَḥ ْtَyʾِlُm āَhāَnْdَjgَwَf َءāَmَّslā āَnْsَmَl āَّnَaʾَw
āًdَṣَّr āًbāَhِhs ُhَl ْdِjgَy َnāʾْlā ِʿعِmَtْsَy nَmَf ۖ ِʿعْmَّslِl َdِʿعāَqَm āَhْnِm ُdُʿعْqَn āَّnُk āَّnَaʾَw

footnotes.text: Before the prophethood of Muḥammad (ﷺ) the jinn used to collect information by eavesdropping on the angels and then pass it on to fortunetellers and soothsayers.

ayas.translation: āًdَhsَr ْmُhُّbَr ْmِhِb َdāَrَaʾ ْmَaʾ ِḍْrَaʾْlā yِf nَmِb َdyِrُaʾ ٌّrَhsَaʾ yِrْdَn āَl āَّnَaʾَw

footnotes.text: In opinion, belief and religious practice.

ayas.translation: āًbَrَh ُhَzِjgْʿعُّn nَlَw ِḍْrَaʾْlā yِf َhَّllā َzِjgْʿعُّn nَّl nَaʾ āَّnَnَẓ āَّnَaʾَw
āًqَhَr āَlَw āًsْhkَb ُfāَhkَy āَlَf ِhِّbَrِb nِmْwʾُy nَmَf ۖ ِhِb āَّnَmāʾ ٰyَdُhْlā āَnْʿعِmَs āَّmَl āَّnَaʾَw

footnotes.text: In regard to his account in the Hereafter. Nothing of his good will be diminished, nor will the evil of another be placed upon him.
i.e., those who deviate from the truth and act tyrannically.
i.e., refuses obedience to Him.
The term "masjid" here includes every place of worship or the earth in general.
Or "worship."
Crowding on top of each other in the manner of locusts in order to hear him (ﷺ). "They" may refer to the jinn or to the disbelievers among the Arabs.
Guardian angels to protect the messenger and the message.
This phrase may also be read: "So He [i.e., Allāh] may make evident."
Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā) addresses the Prophet (ﷺ), who was asleep, wrapped in his garments.
i.e., the revelation, which when descending on the Prophet (ﷺ) bore down upon him with a great weight. Another meaning is "important ordinances."
Another accepted interpretation of the same words is "Indeed, arising at night is more difficult...," meaning that it will only be done by sincere believers and not others.
i.e., for recitation of the Qur’ān and for hearing and understanding it.
i.e., trust in Allāh and rely upon Him.

ayas.translation: āًlwُsَr َnْwَʿعْrِf ٰyَlِiʾ āَnْlَsْrَaʾ āَmَk ْmُkْyَlَʿع āًdِhāَhs āًlwُsَr ْmُkْyَlِiʾ āَnْlَsْrَaʾ āَّnِiʾ

footnotes.text: Another meaning is "How can you avoid [punishment]" on such a Day?
From the terror of that Day.

ayas.translation: ٌmyِḥَّr ٌrwُfَغ َhَّllā َّnِiʾ ۖ َhَّllā āwُrِfْغَtْsāَw ۚ āًrْjgَaʾ َmَẓْʿعَaʾَw āًrْyَhk َwُh ِhَّllā َdnِʿع ُhwُdِjgَt ٍrْyَhk ْnِّm mُkِsُfnَaʾِl āwُmِّdَqُt āَmَw ۚ āًnَsَḥ āًḍْrَq َhَّllā āwُḍِrْqَaʾَw َhāَkَّzlā āwُtāʾَw َhāَlَّṣlā āwُmyِqَaʾَw ۚ ُhْnِm َrَّsَyَt āَm āwُءَrْqāَf ۖ ِhَّllā ِlyِbَs yِf َnwُlِtāَqُy َnwُrَhkāʾَw ۙ ِhَّllā ِlْḍَf nِm َnwُغَtْbَy ِḍْrَaʾْlā yِf َnwُbِrْḍَy َnwُrَhkāʾَw ۙ ٰyَḍْrَّm mُknِm ُnwُkَyَs nَaʾ َmِlَʿع ۚ ِnāʾْrُqْlā َnِm َrَّsَyَt āَm āwُءَrْqāَf ۖ ْmُkْyَlَʿع َbāَtَf ُhwُṣْḥُt nَّl nَaʾ َmِlَʿع ۚ َrāَhَّnlāَw َlْyَّllā ُrِّdَqُy ُhَّllāَw ۚ َkَʿعَm َnyِhdَّlā َnِّm ٌhَfِyʾāَṭَw ُhَhtُlُhtَw ُhَfْṣِnَw ِlْyَّllā ِyَhtُlُht nِm ٰyَnْdَaʾ ُmwُqَt َkَّnَaʾ ُmَlْʿعَy َkَّbَr َّnِiʾ

footnotes.text: Allāh has known that if they were to continue in such long periods of worship each night, the people would be caused much hardship.
In the form of charities and contributions to His cause.
Referring to the Prophet (ﷺ).
Specifically, idols or generally, bad conduct and morals.
An alternative meaning is "Do not consider any favor you have conferred to be great."
i.e., without wealth or children. The reference is to al-Waleed bin al-Mugheerah, who after inclining toward the Qur’ān, denied it publicly in order to win the approval of the Quraysh.
About what he would say concerning the Qur’ān and how he might discredit the Prophet (ﷺ).
One of the proper names of Hell.

ayas.translation: ِrَhsَbْlِl ٰyَrْkِhd āَّlِiʾ َyِh āَmَw ۚ َwُh āَّlِiʾ َkِّbَr َdwُnُjg ُmَlْʿعَy āَmَw ۚ ُءāَhsَy nَm yِdْhَyَw ُءāَhsَy nَm ُhَّllā ُّlِḍُy َkِlَٰhdَk ۚ āًlَhtَm āَhdٰـَhِb ُhَّllā َdāَrَaʾ āَhdāَm َnwُrِfāَkْlāَw ٌḍَrَّm mِhِbwُlُq yِf َnyِhdَّlā َlwُqَyِlَw ۙ َnwُnِmْwʾُmْlāَw َbāَtِkْlā āwُtwُaʾ َnyِhdَّlā َbāَtْrَy āَlَw ۙ āًnāَmyِiʾ āwُnَmāʾ َnyِhdَّlā َdāَdْzَyَw َbāَtِkْlā āwُtwُaʾ َnyِhdَّlā َnِqْyَtْsَyِl āwُrَfَk َnyِhdَّlِّl ًhَnْtِf āَّlِiʾ ْmُhَtَّdِʿع āَnْlَʿعَjg āَmَw ۙ ًhَkِyʾāَlَm āَّlِiʾ ِrāَّnlā َbāَḥْṣَaʾ āَnْlَʿعَjg āَmَw

footnotes.text: To righteousness by acceptance of the warning.
i.e., subject or held responsible.
i.e., the righteous who receive their records in their right hands.
Instead of Muḥammad (ﷺ).
i.e., made public. Much of their refusal of his message was due to envy and jealousy of the Prophet (ﷺ).
i.e., that of the believer, which blames him when he falls into sin or error.
Literally, "to sin ahead of him." This refers to the disbeliever, who denies the Day of Account.
i.e., his deeds, which await him in the Hereafter.
i.e., that which he did not do or which he delayed.
As described in <reference chapter="36" verses="65">36:65</reference> and <reference chapter="41" verses="20-23">41:20-23</reference>.
The people of Paradise will actually see their Creator in the Hereafter.
At the time it is about to leave the body when one is on the verge of death.
From the difficulties the person faces at death or his sudden awareness of the realities of both this world and the Hereafter. It may also refer to his shrouding after death.
Literally, "driving" or "herding" or "the place to which one is driven."
i.e., to no end, without responsibility, or without being returned to the Creator for judgement.
i.e., a combination of the male and female substance, within the womb.
A sweet-smelling spring in Paradise.
The meaning here may also be "out of love for Him," i.e., Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā).

ayas.translation: āًryِrَṭْmَq āًswُbَʿع āًmْwَy āَnِّbَّr nِm ُfāَhkَn āَّnِiʾ
āًryِrَhْmَz āَlَw āًsْmَhs āَhyِf َnْwَrَy āَl ۖ ِkِyʾāَrَaʾْlā yَlَʿع āَhyِf َnyِyʾِkَّtُّm

footnotes.text: i.e., neglect. The meaning may also be "leave ahead of them."
To Allāh's human messengers.
i.e., when they are gathered to witness concerning their nations. The sentence's conclusion is understood to be "...the promised judgement will then take place."
"It" may refer to either the aforementioned occurrences collectively or to the testimony of the messengers.
i.e., death and destruction.
i.e., the Resurrection.
To stabilize the land and balance the earth.
Covering you in darkness and providing rest.
In proportion to and comparable with their crimes.
This announcement will be made to the companions of Hell.
Of security, success and reward, including escape and safety from Hell.
Of wine which is delicious and does not intoxicate.
i.e., as a result of both their own righteous deeds and the limitless generosity of Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā) . Another meaning is "a gift calculated [to be adequate]."
None of Allāh's creatures can plead with Him on the Day of Judgement except by His permission.
i.e., a direct route through correct beliefs and righteous deeds.

ayas.translation: āًbāَrُt ُtnُk yِnَtْyَl āَy ُrِfāَkْlā ُlwُqَyَw ُhāَdَy ْtَmَّdَq āَm ُءْrَmْlā ُrُẓnَy َmْwَy āًbyِrَq āًbāَhdَʿع ْmُkāَnْrَhdnَaʾ āَّnِiʾ

footnotes.text: i.e., the deeds he did in this world, which await him in the Hereafter.
i.e., those who tear out the souls of those destined for Hell.
i.e., those angels who ease out the souls of those destined for Paradise.
Speeding to execute Allāh's commands.
Racing to deliver the souls of the believers to Paradise.
According to Allāh's decree.
Those of the disbelievers who denied the Resurrection.
Those of the disbelievers.
The disbelievers say this in ridicule of the warning.
i.e., "If that were so, we would not be able to escape punishment."
i.e., the miracle of his staff becoming a great snake.
An alternative meaning is "running [from the snake]."
i.e., for Pharaoh's setting himself up as a deity and for his previous oppression of the people and denial of Moses.
i.e., created the day from within the surrounding darkness.
i.e., the Day of Resurrection.
See footnote to <reference chapter="55" verses="46">55:46</reference>.
Literally, "resting" or "establishment."
Meaning that Muḥammad (ﷺ) had no knowledge of it, so how could he inform them?
i.e., its destination and termination. And to Him belongs ultimate knowledge of it.
i.e., the Hour, the Resurrection.
ʿAbdullāh, the son of Umm Maktūm.
As a result of what he learns from you.
i.e., without need of faith or need of Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā) . Here it is in reference to a certain influential member of the Quraysh whom the Prophet (ﷺ) had hoped to bring to Islām.
The Prophet (ﷺ) was responsible only for conveying the message, not for ultimate guidance.
The revelation. Or "Him," i.e., Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā) .
i.e., those who deny Allāh's message.
His proportions, provisions, life span, etc.
Into this world (i.e., his birth) . It may also refer to life itself, which has been made easier by Allāh's guidance.
To conceal his decaying body.
The piercing blast of the Horn which signals resurrection. Aṣ-Ṣākhkhah is also a name for the Day of Resurrection.
i.e., to occupy him. He will be concerned only with himself, thus forgetting all others.
Those ten months pregnant and nearing delivery. This verse alludes to distraction from the most valued of possessions.
Or "when the seas have overflowed [into each other]."
With another like soul. It can also mean "joined" (with their groups or sects) .
On which are recorded the deeds of all people.
i.e., all of one's deeds from worldly life, which have accompanied the soul to the Hereafter.
An alternative meaning is "as it departs."
Literally, "possessed by jinn."
i.e., the eastern horizon, where the sun rises. See footnote to <reference chapter="53" verses="6">53:6</reference>.
Prophet Muḥammad (ﷺ) did not withhold that knowledge of the unseen which Allāh had revealed to him in the Qur’ān.
In your denial of the Qur’ān and in your accusations against the Prophet (ﷺ) . The meaning is essentially "Surely, you have strayed far from Allāh's path."
Angels who preserve the deeds of men in records.
i.e., those who cheat people by giving them less than what they paid for when weighing or measuring - an amount so little as to hardly be noticed.
The lowest depths of Hell.
i.e., their sins.
i.e., they will not be able to see Him.
The highest elevations of Paradise.
Which is delicious and does not intoxicate.
i.e., its lingering odor.
The highest spring in Paradise and the most favored drink of its inhabitants.
On the Day of Judgement.
It will have heard Allāh's command and will have inclined immediately to compliance and willing obedience.
i.e., stretched flat and spread out.
Of the dead and all else buried therein.
i.e., striving throughout your life until you meet your Lord, hastening toward death.
i.e., you will find all that you intended and accomplished awaiting you in the Hereafter. Another meaning is "And will meet Him [i.e., your Lord]" and be recompensed in full by Him.
i.e., various stages, both in this life and in the Hereafter.

Or "May they be destroyed" or "cursed." The "companions of the trench" (or ditch) were agents of a tyrannical king who refused to allow his people to believe in Allāh. Their evil deed in obedience to their ruler earned for them the curse of Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā) .
After casting the believers into a trench filled with fire, they sat at its edge, watching them burn to death. This event occurred before the time of Prophet Muḥammad (ﷺ) .
See footnote to <reference chapter="4" verses="79">4:79</reference>.
Or, in this instance, the literal meaning of "burned" is also appropriate.
See footnote to <reference chapter="2" verses="19">2:19</reference>
Whose light pierces through the darkness.
i.e., exposed, examined and judged.
Rain, heat, sound waves, etc.
With plant growth or from geological rifts.
i.e., Do not be in haste for revenge, for you will see what will become of them.
To the path of Allāh's religion, which is easy and natural, or toward Paradise, by giving opportunities for righteous deeds.
i.e., wherever it will be heard and understood.

Another accepted meaning is "They were working hard and exhausted," i.e., doing deeds during worldly life which did not benefit them since they were not accompanied by faith or done for the acceptance of Allāh (subḥānahu wa taʿālā) .
i.e., any insult, falsehood, immorality, idle or vain talk, etc.
Usually interpreted as the first ten nights of the month of Dhul-Ḥijjah.
Based upon the following verses, what has been sworn to by Allāh is that He will certainly punish the disbelievers.
Another name for the first people of ʿAad, to whom Prophet Hūd was sent.
Supporting their tents or buildings.
By which he tortured people.
He is proud rather than grateful, attributing the favor to his own merit.
It is not like you imagine. Rather, Allāh tries people through prosperity and hardship and rewards both gratitude and patience with honor in the Hereafter.
Not caring whether it is lawful or unlawful.
To pass judgement. See footnote to <reference chapter="2" verses="19">2:19</reference>.
The everlasting life of the Hereafter.
Said to be Adam (upon him be peace) .
Of good and evil.
i.e., the steep incline or obstacle. In other words, he has not spent in the cause of Allāh but only boasts of spending in front of others.
Or "the companions of good fortune," i.e., those who receive their records in their right hands and proceed to Paradise.
Or "the companions of ill fortune," i.e., those who receive their records in their left hands and proceed to Hell.
The cover over Hell will be sealed and locked, containing its fire and its inhabitants.
The earth. Also interpreted as the sun. The same applies to the following verse.
i.e., balanced and refined it, creating in it sound tendencies and consciousness.
To hamstring the she-camel which had been sent by Allāh as a sign to them.
And then killed.
Allāh is not asked about what He does, but His servants will be asked. See <reference chapter="21" verses="23">21:23</reference>.
With darkness.
i.e., when he dies or is destroyed. It can also mean when he falls into the Hellfire.
i.e., without intending reciprocation for some benefit to himself.
And becomes still.
Anyone who seeks aid or knowledge.
i.e., enlighten, assure and gladden your heart with guidance.
By forgiving any errors which you may have committed previously or might commit consequently. "Burden" can also refer to the anxiety experienced by the Prophet (ﷺ) at the beginning of his mission.
Referring to the places known for their production, i.e., Damascus and Jerusalem, respectively. It could also refer to the fig and olive trees or to the fruits themselves.
i.e., upright, symmetrical, and balanced in form and nature.
This can refer to the depths of Hell, to decrepit old age or to immorality.
More literally, "What makes you lie concerning it?"
It may also mean "slap him" or "blacken his face at the forelock."
Those who push the wicked into the Fire.
Bringing the exact measures apportioned for everything by Allāh in the course of the coming year.
Upon the believers.
i.e., from their erroneous beliefs and superstitions.
i.e., containing no falsehood.
Into sects and denominations.

ayas.translation: ِhَmِّyَqْlā ُnyِd َkِlَٰhdَw ۚ َhāَkَّzlā āwُtْwʾُyَw َhāَlَّṣlā āwُmyِqُyَw َءāَfَnُḥ َnyِّdlā ُhَl َnyِṣِlْhkُm َhَّllā āwُdُbْʿعَyِl āَّlِiʾ āwُrِmُaʾ āَmَw
ُhَّbَr َyِhsَhk ْnَmِl َkِlَٰhd ۚ ُhْnَʿع āwُḍَrَw ْmُhْnَʿع ُhَّllā َyِḍَّr ۖ āًdَbَaʾ āَhyِf َnyِdِlāَhk ُrāَhْnَaʾْlā āَhِtْḥَt nِm yِrْjgَt ٍnْdَʿع ُtāَّnَjg ْmِhِّbَr َdnِʿع ْmُhُwʾāَzَjg

footnotes.text: See <reference chapter="84" verses="4">verse 84:4</reference>.
In terror and amazement.
From the place of Judgement to their final abode. Another interpretation is "emerge separately" (from the graves) .
Or "the weight of a small ant."
i.e., the horses bearing riders as they race to attack the enemy.
Their hoofs while galloping over rocky terrain.
While the enemy is unaware.
i.e., penetrating into the enemy ranks during a surprise attack.
Through his speech and his actions.
i.e., when all secrets are made known.
Fully acquainted and familiar with everything about each one of them.
The people will be as such after having been expelled from their graves.
i.e., beginning to disintegrate.
Literally, "mother" (a man's original refuge) , which will envelop him as in an embrace.
i.e., the pit of Hellfire.
i.e., remain in them temporarily, meaning until the Day of Resurrection.
The conclusion of this verse is estimated to be "...you would not have been distracted from preparing for the Hereafter."
i.e., with actual eyesight.
i.e., the comforts of worldly life and whether you were grateful to Allāh for His blessings.
An oath in which Allāh swears by time throughout the ages.
Rather than spending in the way of Allāh.
i.e., Hellfire, which crushes and destroys all that enters it.
Covering them and penetrating them.
Interpreted to be either columns of fire or columns of iron to which are chained the inmates of Hell.
i.e., the army under the command of Abrahah al-Ashram which was accompanied by a huge elephant and came with the intention of destroying the Kaʿbah at Makkah.
Causing them to perish.
i.e., husks which have been chewed by cattle. This event took place in the year of the Prophet's birth.
i.e., the honor and reputation Allāh had given them as guardians of the Holy Kaʿbah, which allowed them to travel without fear of being harmed.
i.e., the trading caravans that traveled south in winter and north in summer.
i.e., the Kaʿbah.
i.e., the hypocrites who are unconcerned if they miss prayers when no one sees them.
From all good in this world and the Hereafter.
The conquest of Makkah.
Refer to footnote of <reference chapter="2" verses="37">2:37</reference>.
Abū Lahab (the Prophet's uncle) , who was an enemy of Islām.
She used to put thorns in the Prophet's path and slander him (ﷺ) . The word "firewood" was used by the Arabs to allude to slander and backbiting.
Alone, without another, indivisible with absolute and permanent unity and distinct from all else. The one and only true deity, unique in His essence, attributes and deeds.

He who is absolute, perfect, complete, essential, self-sufficient and sufficient to meet the needs of all creation; the one eternally and constantly required and sought, depended upon by all existence and to whom all matters will ultimately return.
i.e., those who practice magic.
i.e., a devil who makes evil suggestions to man but disappears when one remembers Allāh.
Evil prompters may be from men as well as from jinn.
